Issues.Title: feat(compiler-cli): add check for numeric CSS properties requiring units
Issues.Body:
# Feat: Add Numeric CSS Property Requires Unit Diagnostic ## Overview This PR introduces a new extended template diagnostic to Angular's compiler: **NumericCssPropertyRequiresUnit**. It warns developers when a numeric value is bound to a CSS property that requires a unit (e.g., `[style.width]="500"`), which would have no effect in the browser. The diagnostic suggests using a unit suffix (e.g., `[style.width.px]="500"` or `[style.width]="'500px'"`). ## Motivation Binding numeric values to CSS properties without units is a common source of confusion and bugs. Browsers ignore such values, leading to unexpected UI behavior. This diagnostic helps developers catch these mistakes early and provides actionable suggestions. ## Example ```html
``` Diagnostic Message > Binding a number to the CSS property 'width' will have no effect. CSS requires units for length values. E.g Use '[style.width.px]="500"' or '[style.width]="'500px'"' instead. ## Impact - **Developer Experience**: Improves DX by catching subtle template bugs. - **Backward Compatibility**: No breaking changes. Only adds a warning for incorrect usage. - **Extensibility**: Easily extendable to more CSS properties if needed. [Related Issue] https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/61381

Issues.Title: Provide some mechanism for HTTP errors to fall back to global ErrorHandler when withFetch / FetchBackend is enabled
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

common

### Description

My team just attempted to enable `withFetch()` in our application and encountered a pretty major footgun - because the FetchBackend runs outside the Angular zone, any HTTP errors, JSON parsing errors, etc. that occur and aren't caught downstream in a subscription go completely uncaught. If the HTTP request occurred during server side rendering, this results in the app _crashing_ altogether.

This was unexpected and we only diagnosed why our app was crashing in certain environments after doing some very deep server-side debugging into the source of the error. This difference isn't documented anywhere that I can find.

### Proposed solution

It would be helpful if there was some mechanism to ensure that errors that occur during HTTP requests when the HttpClient is configured with `withFetch` are still able to fall back to the global error handler. I'm not sure what that would look like -- maybe configuration that can be passed into the `withFetch()` call?

### Alternatives considered

Everywhere we make an HTTP request _should_ already have explicit error handling, but there are a lot of places that don't have it in our codebase. These are mostly not on purpose (just oversights when implementing new features years ago), and those places have never caused any major issues because the global error handler catches the errors when HttpClient uses the XHR backend.

We already have logging set up in our global error handler to inform us when server-side network requests are failing like this so we can address them and add proper error handling, and for the sake of reliability we would prefer to catch failing network requests this way (rather than the entire application going down in production.) Our global error handler also adds some metadata to these errors that can be helpful when debugging; the app crashing altogether is a lot harder to debug because the error is more confusing and does not include that metadata.

Thank you!

Issues.Body: ### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? compiler ### Is this a regression? No ### Description Code like this: ``` @let foo = '{{bar}} baz'; ``` is syntax highlghted in the official playground as though those braces are interpolation braces. But they are not interpolated; the string is just the literal string above. Prettier also formats the contents of these interpolation braces as though they were interpolated, leading to added whitespace inside the string. I've seen at least one production issue resulting from this where the code author assumed the braces would be interpolated. If the intent really is to not interpolate in this one specific instance, I'd suggest that it should be an error to include `{{` in a @let assigned string without escaping it. ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug _No response_ ### Please provide the exception or error you saw ```true ``` ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true ``` ### Anything else? _No response_

Issues.Title: test(@angular/cli): add CI validation for MCP example code
Issues.Body:
This commit introduces a new CI check to validate the correctness of code snippets and markdown structure within the `find_examples` markdown files.

To support this, the previous the `example_db_generator.js` script has been refactored and consolidated into a single, unified, mode-driven script: `process_examples.mjs`. This improves maintainability and ensures consistent parsing and validation logic.

The new script provides two new validation modes for CI:
- `validate-structure`: Parses all examples to validate their front matter and ensure they adhere to the required markdown heading structure.
- `validate-code`: Uses a pre-built Angular application harness to perform a full `ng build` on all example code, ensuring compilation and template correctness.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/ssr): introduce BootstrapContext for isolated server-side rendering
Issues.Body:
This commit introduces a number of changes to the server bootstrapping process to make it more robust and less error-prone, especially for concurrent requests.

Previously, the server rendering process relied on a module-level global platform injector. This could lead to issues in server-side rendering environments where multiple requests are processed concurrently, as they could inadvertently share or overwrite the global injector state.

The new approach introduces a `BootstrapContext` that is passed to the `bootstrapApplication` function. This context provides a platform reference that is scoped to the individual request, ensuring that each server-side render has an isolated platform injector. This prevents state leakage between concurrent requests and makes the overall process more reliable.

BREAKING CHANGE:
The server-side bootstrapping process has been changed to eliminate the reliance on a global platform injector.

Before:
```ts
const bootstrap = () => bootstrapApplication(AppComponent, config);
```

After:
```ts
const bootstrap = (context: BootstrapContext) =>
  bootstrapApplication(AppComponent, config, context);
```

Issues.Title: fix(material/progress-bar): avoid CSP issues due to buffer dots
Issues.Body:
Currently the way we render the buffer dots in the progress bar is by using a `data:` URL with an inline SVG. The problem with this approach is that it can trigger CSP errors and require users to allow all `data:` URLs, even if they don't use the buffer mode.

These changes work around the issue by rendering the dots using a radial gradient instead.

Fixes #31808.
